items.message: River levels remain high in the River Rye catchment due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include land around the River Rye and it's tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, Spittle Beck, including properties of Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. Further rain is forecast for the next few days and we expect levels to rise further. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen overnight on the River Seven Catchment, however they remain high and are expected to rise further due to ongoing rainfall forecast for the next few days. Areas most at risk include land around the River Seven and it's tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, including properties in Sinnington and to the east of Normanby. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Camel, River Allen, Bodmin Town Leat, River Valency
River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible in these areas. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the weekend before an improved forecast for early next week. 
The Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and Lake Windermere will remain high today, but we do not expect any flooding to properties.
We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend. 
Newby Bridge sluices remain open due to high lake levels. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Lake levels on Derwent Water and river levels in Borrowdale remain high due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and low lying areas in Borrowdale.
River and lake levels are expected to remain high throughout Saturday and into Sunday.
Further light rainfall is forecast on Saturday and Sunday before the forecast improves early in the week.
We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Lake levels on Derwent Water remain high due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
Lake levels are expected to remain high throughout Saturday and into Sunday.
Further light rainfall is forecast on Saturday and Sunday keeping lake levels high at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely over the weekend.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 21:00 on Sunday, 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are now falling steadily, but still remain quite high in some locations. Further showers are expected, mostly tomorrow (Sunday) but these are not expected to require issuing of a further flood alert.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding in the River Dart area has now reduced, the rainfall forecast reduced overnight and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the weekend and we will continue to monitor the situation

River levels are now falling on the Upper River Aire catchment following the recent rainfall. Levels remain elevated in the Kildwick area but are expected to fall throughout tonight, Saturday 18th November.
Whilst levels are now starting to fall, further rainfall over the weekend means that levels are likely to remain elevated and there could be some localised surface water flooding.
We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected along riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. We expect levels to stay high over the next few days and are expected to rise a little further on Monday 20/11/2023 due to further forecast rain. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 7pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Foss due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk of flooding are around the River Foss upstream of Yearsley Baths to Strensall. Further rainfall is forecast intermittently overnight and tomorrow, 19/11/2023. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 11am on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include the upper Derwent areas, including land around Old Malton, Low Marishes and Priorpot Beck in Norton. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the lower River Derwent due to recent heavy rain. Areas most at risk include local roads and low-lying land around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and levels are expected to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please monitor local weather and river conditions and avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are steady on the River Thame as a result of overnight rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame, Stadhampton, and Dorchester areas. Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
The Washford River remains high but is now slowly falling and is not expected to rise again over the next few days. There may remain some limited flooding of low-lying land and roads in and around the Washford River. The Horner Water, River Aller, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream and Doniford Stream are now back to normal winter base flow levels. 
Please consider the weather conditions and local water levels and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.
This message will be updated by 11 am on 20/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message:
The overnight band of rainfall has now pass out of the area but there is still the possibility of showers for the rest of the weekend and into Monday. River levels on the River Tone and the Halsewater Stream are still slowly rising but are not as high as previously forecast and are currently below the Flood Alert criteria. This Flood Alert remains in force whilst the river continues to rise.  Levels on the Hillfarrance Brook have peaked and now falling. The flooding of low-lying land and roads is still possible, but no property flooding is expected at this time. 
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 1pm on Sunday 19/11/2023.

No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the weekend and we will continue to monitor the situation.

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk of flooding are around the River Foulness and the Market Weighton Canal and their tributaries. Further rainfall is forecast intermittently overnight and tomorrow, 19/11/2023. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 11am on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham
items.message: River levels remain high on Broadlane Beck and Creyke Beck due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include properties around King Street, Northgate, Dunswell Road, and North Moor Lane. This means properties are at risk of flooding. Levels are falling however further rainfall is forecast for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message: River levels remain high in the Cottingham area due to recent rainfall. The areas most at risk include Cottingham, Kirk Ella, Anlaby and Hessle. Levels are falling however further rain is forecast for the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated at 7pm on 19/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.34 m and is slowly falling. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.74 m and is slowly falling. 
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
We continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels closely and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.  
We are pumping at Currymoor and Saltmoor pumping stations when river levels allow and have deployed additional temporary pumps at both stations and at Elsonâ€™s Clyce. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 1pm on Monday 20 November.
This alert has now been removed due to conditions improving. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue if necessary.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin from 3pm this afternoon, 18/11/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech initial peak 2.9 to 3.3m expected this evening followed by another peak of between 3.5 to 4.0m Sunday evening. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 19/11/23, or as the situation changes

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued by the Environment Agency. 

Flood Alert in force: Lower Avon and tributaries. 

Flooding is possible for: Tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.    

Be prepared.

 River levels are high but steady at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Wednesday, 22/11/23, or as the situation changes. 

To check the latest information for your area

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are beginning to slowly fall on the River Blackwater following the recent rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. It is forecast to be largely dry this evening and overnight 18/11/23. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 19/11/23 or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels have fallen following rainfall last week. However, levels in York remain high and further rainfall is forecast. Levels are expected to stay high and rise a little further on Monday. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 7pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 18th November 2023. The river is reacting in response to the rainfall overnight. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the Deben from Debenham to Ufford, including Framsden, Earl Soham, Easton, Glevering and Wickham Market, and on the Rivers Lark and Finn around Witnesham, Tuddenham St Martin, Playford and Grundisburgh. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Saturday 18th November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day with light rain forecast. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high and are falling slowly at the Tern - Walcot and Rodington river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days with further peaks possible.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Leek river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this morning.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 17:00 on 18/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Saturday 18th November. Water levels continue to remain high and may last for the next few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent rainfall across the area. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The weather forecast is for light rain today, Saturday 18th November. Further rain is due tomorrow. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Dove Brooks and Egginton Brook in Derbyshire

floodArea.riverOrSea: Egginton Brook, Foston Brook, Hilton Brook

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Mill river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Foston Brook, Hilton Brook and Egginton Brook.   
We expect river levels to rise until later this afternoon.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated In the next 8 hours.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 18th November 2023. The river is reacting in response to the rainfall overnight. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Saturday 18th November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day with light rain forecast. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels continue to remain high on the Bristol Avon at Bradford-on-Avon and the Semington Brook at Semington. Approximately 5 to 10 mm of rain has fallen in the last 24 hours over the catchment. The unsettled weather continues, further rain is expected today, Saturday the 18th November and Sunday the 19th November, which will continue to maintain high river levels. No Flood Warnings are currently forecast to be issued in this Flood Alert area.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Friday morning, or sooner if the situation changes.

River levels continue to remain high on Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon and Dauntsey Brook and the Sherston Avon. Approximately 5 to 10 mm of rain has fallen in the last 24 hours over the catchment. The unsettled weather continues, further rain is expected today, Saturday the 18th November and Sunday the 19th November, which will continue to maintain high river levels. No Flood Warnings are currently forecast to be issued in this Flood Alert area.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, or sooner if the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are steady on the River Thames as a result of previous rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Abingdon and Culham areas.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar are high. Rainfall overnight and this morning was less than forecast. Only 10mm has been recorded at Wroxall. While this is a relatively small amount of rain, it will be sufficient to cause the river level to rise around Alverstone until 18:00 today (18/11/2023). At Sandown, the level could rise until around 08:00 on Sunday (19/11/2023), when some minor flood impacts to roads and gardens are possible. At Alverstone, minor impact flooding to roads and gardens is possible overnight and into Sunday (19/11/2023). From today, no further impactful rain is forecast, so water levels should slowly return to normal for the time of year. This Flood Alert will remain in force until the river level measured at Sandown has fallen to 1.07mAOD and minor impacts are no longer expected. We will continue to manage the water level at Bembridge and monitor the forecast. This message will be updated by 15:00 on 19/11/2023.

items.description: The Rivers Blyth and Walpole and Chediston, Bramfield and Wrentham watercourses
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 18th November 2023. The River is reacting quickly, and rising sharply in response to the rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Halesworth, Wissett, Chediston, Walpole, Huntingfield, Bramfield and Wrentham. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Saturday 18th November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day with light rain forecast. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River East Glen, River West Glen, River Tham

items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Glen area. This means that the River Glen is now rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from the afternoon of Saturday, 18th November onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the weekend and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 12:00 on 19/11/23, or before if the situation changes.

items.message:
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
The river levels in the River Yeo at Sherborne Lake have fallen but may rise again during Sunday. This Flood Alert remains in force as a precaution as there may be the risk of continuing limited flooding of low-lying land and roads in this area. The River Yeo, the River Cam and River Wriggle have now all fallen to normal winter base flow levels.
Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 12 pm on Monday 20/11/2023.

items.message:

River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue, especially in the Chertsey area. It is forecast to be largely dry this evening and overnight 18/11/23. We expect river levels to begin to slowly fall.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Saturday 18th November 2023. The river is reacting in response to the rainfall overnight. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the River Box from Little Waldingfield to Thorrington Street, including Boxford, and on the River Brett from Cockfield to Higham, including Hadleigh. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Saturday 18th November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day with light rain forecast. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days with further peaks possible.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the Ginge Brook as a result of overnight rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, especially in the Steventon area.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high due to rises at the Slad Steanbridge Lane river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today Saturday 18/11/20223. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 10 am on Sunday 19/11/23 or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the lower River Nidd catchment due to recent rainfall. The areas most at risk include land around the Lower River Nidd and its tributaries including Sand Beck, Sike Beck, Pool Beck and Great Gutter. Further showers are forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated at 9am on 19/11/23 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Evenlode and River Glyme as a result of overnight rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Woodstock area.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling slowly, on the River Ray as a result of previous rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, especially in the Lower Arncott area.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. We expect river levels to begin rising again this afternoon 18/11/23 as a result of overnight rain.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are steady on the River Pang and Sulham Brook as a result of overnight rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Sulham area. Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because there may be some issues with surface water flooding and difficult driving conditions today, Saturday 18th November 2023. The River is reacting quickly, and rising sharply in response to the rainfall. Areas most at risk are the Thoroughfare, Chediston Street, Saxons Way and School Lane in Halesworth, and the A144 and the railway line at Halesworth. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Saturday 18th November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day with light rain forecast. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Sunday 19th November, or as the situation changes.

River levels in Hellingly and Alfriston are slowly starting to rise following Saturday morning's rain (18/11/2023). Only minimal flood impacts affecting fields and rural roads are currently expected in both Hellingly and Alfriston. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers will rise again. Property flooding could be possible in both Hellingly and Alfriston. In Alfriston, the river could remain higher than normal all week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Tewks. Upper Pound river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. Levels have now peaked. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Churn as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Cerney Wick area.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Thames as a result of previous rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially between the Lechlade and Eynsham areas. Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York as a result of recent rainfall. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, particularly around properties along Queens Staith on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place, St Georges Field car parks and Rowntree Park. Levels in York at the Viking recorder have started rising again overnight and are now around 3m. We expect levels to stay around this over the next few days and are expected to rise a little further on Monday 20/11/23 due to further forecast rain. We will continue to monitor the forecast. The Foss Barrier is being operated. Please monitor local water levels and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect riverside properties, properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Levels in York at the Viking recorder have started rising again overnight and are now around 3m. We expect levels to stay around this level over the next few days due to further forecast rain. The Foss Barrier is in operation. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
This information is correct as of 17:00 on Saturday 18 November 2023. 
The causeway at Welney has 3 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency is liaising with Cambridge and Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road.
There is no significant rainfall forecast over the next few days. There are no issues on Sutton Gault causeway and Earith causeway. We will continue to monitor the situation.
We will update this message by 09:00 on Sunday 19 November 2023.

This flood warning has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. There is further rain forecast at the weekend, over the next few days, and we will reissue this warning if necessary.

The Western Rother remains high in Fittleworth. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads will continue in Fittleworth. The Western Rother will rise a small amount in all communities following this Saturday's rain (18/11/2023), but minor flood impacts are only expected in Fittleworth. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The Western Rother will rise again. It is currently thought flood impacts will remain minor, affecting fields, gardens and rural roads. However, from Saturday evening (18/11/2023) flood water could potentially approach properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. River levels in Fittleworth could be higher than normal all week. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

items.message: The risk of flooding in the River Axe area has now reduced, as the rainfall forecast reduced overnight and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the weekend and we will continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message:
The Flood Alert has now been removed.Â 
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Aldingbourne Rife will start to slowly rise following Saturday's rain (18/11/2023). The Barnham Rife is already starting to rise. Flood impacts will continue in Bersted. Isolated property flooding could also be possible in Barnham on Saturday afternoon (18/11/2023). Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station (HEPS) is 7.97 m and is slowly falling. The drain level at HEPS is 7.82 m and is steady.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
When river levels allow, pumping continues at Huish Episcopi and we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to evacuate water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 1pm on Monday 20/11/2023.
Please consider local water levels and weather conditions and do not walk or drive through flood water.
For water levels on the River Yeo and the drain at HEPS please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).

The Combe Haven in Bulverhythe remains high, and will continue to rise by 30cm over each high tide period. Flooding will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground, and possibly some gardens on Bexhill Road in Bulverhythe. The Powdermill Stream in Crowhurst is high but is not expected to reach the levels seen on Tuesday this week. Only minimal flood impacts are expected in Crowhurst. The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are rising again following Saturday's rain (18/11/2023), and property flooding could be possible from Saturday afternoon. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high. Flooding is thought to still be affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. River levels will start to slowly rise following Saturday's rain (18/11/2023). Showers are forecast on Sunday (19/11/2023), with more rain (5-10mm) forecast for Monday (20/11/2023). The Aldingbourne Rife could rise by about 15cm on Saturday (18/11/2023). With the rest of November forecast to remain unsettled, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
This Flood Alert remains in force due to the flooding of large areas of the Somerset Levels and Moors. Flood water may affect the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road, and the road and properties at the south end of Westover Trading Estate.
We are utilising our pumping stations, including additional temporary pumps, when river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. This message will be updated by 1 pm on Monday 20/11/2023.

River levels have fallen a little overnight on the River Derwent however they remain high and are expected to rise further over the next few days due to further forecast rain. Flooding remains a risk near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe Mill at Buttercrambe Bridge. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 3pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Lower Dorset Frome due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated byÂ 22/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels have fallen a little overnight on the River Derwent however they remain high and are expected to rise further over the next few days due to further forecast rain. The area most at risk is around River Derwent at Stamford Bridge - The Weir Caravan Park and Kexby Bridge. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 3pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on the Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck, River Hull and Roam Drain due to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include the upper Hull area including Kilham, Nafferton, Driffield, Bainton, North Dalton, Leconfield, Leven, Brandesburton, North Frodingham and Beeford. Further rain is forecast for the next few days and we expect levels to stay high. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8pm on 19/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are falling on the Lower River Loddon. It is forecast to be largely dry this evening and overnight 18/11/23. We expect river levels to continue to fall. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing.

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 19/11/23 or if the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
River levels are high but steady as rainfall eases.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

The flood forecast has changed. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No property flooding is expected and river levels are falling.
The forecast is dry for throughout the afternoonÂ and evening.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels are remaining high on the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, River Nadder.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, River Nadder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow morning.
River levels are remaining high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  

It is forecast to be largely dry this evening and overnight 18/11/23. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We have been checking the condition of defences and clearing debris from weed screens.  

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Thames for Henley, Remenham, Medmenham and its tributaries

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Oxfordshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Wokingham
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Assendon Stream, Hambledon Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high but are slowly falling on the River Thames following a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. It is forecast to be largely dry this evening and overnight 18/11/23. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 19/11/23, or if the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.34 m and is slowly falling. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.74 m and is slowly falling. 
A small amount of rain fell overnight and some showers are forecast during Sunday and into Monday but weather is improving and drier conditions are forecast from Tuesday onwards. 
We continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels closely and our staff are checking flood defences and clearing weed screens.  
We are pumping at Currymoor and Saltmoor pumping stations when river levels allow and have deployed additional temporary pumps at both stations and at Elsonâ€™s Clyce. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 1pm on Monday 20 November.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: A gradual easing of conditions over the past week is likely to be reversed following a fresh band of heavy rain in the next 24 hours. We do not expect property flooding at this stage, but some roads, including from Winterborne Abbas to Winterborne Came are likely to be flooded once more. Avoid driving through flood water if at all possible as your bow wave can cause damage to nearby homes. EA staff will continue to monitor the situation locally and will update this message should the situation change.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have remained high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain.

Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Piddle.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham from 09:00 AM on 18/11/2023.
Further light rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
River levels are high but steady, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message: A gradual easing of conditions over the past week is likely to be reversed following a fresh band of heavy rain in the next 24 hours. We do not expect property flooding at this stage, but some roads, including Stubhampton to Tarrant Hinton, Farnham to Gussage St Andrew and Wyke Down to Monkton up Wimborne are likely to be impassable once more. Avoid driving through flood water if at all possible as your bow wave can cause damage to nearby homes. EA staff will continue to monitor the situation locally and will update this message should the situation change.

The River Lavant is high and rising following heavy rain overnight. Minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads and gardens between West Dean and Westhampnett. In East Lavant water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane and the Green, and possibly access bridges over the river. Flood water could affect gardens and approach properties at The Sadlers, Westhampnett. Showers are forecast for Sunday (19/11/2023) and more rain (5-10mm) on Monday (20/11/2023). The river should slowly fall by Sunday morning, but will be higher than normal over the next few days. Land could remain flooded for the next few days. Water levels will remain higher than normal and the river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall. Some roads could be affected by flood water. Plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Sheepwash Lane. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are managing structures in Westhampnett to reduce the flood risk on the River Lavant. We will update this message by 11:00 on 19/11/2023.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high, but falling, on the River Leach as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, especially in the Lechlade area.  Further rain is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 19/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on Bielby Beck due to recent rainfall. River levels are currently steady, below the expected threshold for property flooding, however further rain is forecast for the next few days and levels are expected to stay high. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 3pm 19/11/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hurley to Cookham
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high but are slowly falling on the River Thames from Hurley to Cookham following a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. It is forecast to be largely dry this evening and overnight 18/11/23. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 19/11/23, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, North Somerset, Somerset
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Chew, Chew Stoke Stream, Winford Brook

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
Further rain is expected today, the 18th of November and the 19th November 2023 but limited response expected from the rivers.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
